summary: The sale amount is up from last week's auction, when $25 billion in four-week bills was sold.

summary: What's News: World-Wide for February 1, 2010.

headline: Panasonic Deal Shows Beijing's M&A Clout
summary: Panasonic has agreed to sell a battery business to comply with a Chinese antitrust ruling, highlighting Beijing's growing influence over major global M&A deals.

summary: Corrections & Amplifications for Feb. 2, 2011

headline: New Zealand Leader Sets Election
summary: New Zealand's Prime Minister John Key on Wednesday called a general election for Nov. 26, seeking to avoid letting the outcome of the rugby World Cup to get in the way of politics in a country where the game is a national obsession.

headline: New Zealand Plans Wool Cartel
summary: In a country with more sheep than people, a group of New Zealand farmers plan to create the world's first wool cartel.

Tunisia and Egypt are feeling the most heat. But food inflation isn't just a Mideast problem. The temperature is also rising in Asia. Rice futures hit a 13-month high Tuesday on fears of a supply squeeze as farmers shift production to more-profitable crops like corn and cotton. Soaring rice prices prompted riots back in 2008. A similar move now would really have people steaming.

headline: Massive Day of Protest in Cairo
summary: Hundreds of thousands of Egyptians filed into Cairo's Tahrir Square Tuesday morning, gathering for a massive day of protest to press longtime President Hosni Mubarak to step down.

headline: Evacuees out of Cairo Recall Tense Days
summary: Some of the foreign visitors that have been trying to leave Egypt have faced a frustrating ordeal involving blocked roads, unruly crowds, no cash, and the occasional abuse from overwhelmed airport staff.

headline: Massey Energy Posts Third Straight Quarterly Loss
summary: Massey Energy., which recently agreed to a takeover offer, reported a loss of $70.1 million in the fourth quarter, citing lower productivity in its deep coal mines, inconsistent rail service and port delays, which offset higher prices for coal sold to utilities and steelmakers.

headline: Charlotte Gets Democratic Convention
summary: Democrats said Tuesday they would hold their 2012 presidential-nominating convention in Charlotte, N.C., a signal that they are serious about fighting for North Carolina in the election.

headline: Borders Group Closer to Bankruptcy Filing
summary: Borders Group is hammering out details of a possible bankruptcy filing, according to people familiar with the situation. Among other things, Borders would aim to close between 150 and 200 stores.

headline: Skins Audience Flattens Out
summary: After sparking a wave of controversy among audiences and advertisers alike, MTV's racy new teen show "Skins" appears to have hit a plateau.

headline: All-Cash Gamble by the FDIC
summary: Nearly two years after the failure of Georgia-based Silverton Bank, the FDIC is seeking to unload from its books $385 million of the bank's assets in an all-cash auction.

headline: California Wants Underwriters' Money Back
summary: The California State Treasurer's office is demanding the return of hundreds of thousands of dollars that it says it unwittingly paid bond underwriters who then channeled it into a trade group that lobbied on issues—sometimes going against the grain of the state.

headline: Cyclone Yasi Nears Australia
summary: Australia's flood battered Queensland state is evacuating residents in the face of a fresh cyclone that forecasters warn could be the worst in the tropical region's history.

headline: November Price Chill
summary: In November, prices fell by 2.9% to $1,037.63 per square foot from October, according to real-estate data company Radar Logic's monthly RPX index.

headline: Multinationals Keep Egypt Offices Shut
summary: Multinational companies had no immediate plans to reopen Egyptian offices or bring back evacuated employees after Mubarak's attempt to restore stability failed to placate protesters.

headline: Boston Scientific Posts a Profit
summary: Boston Scientific reported a fourth-quarter profit and higher margins, compared with a loss a year earlier, when it was hit by litigation charges, although the medical-device maker posted lower sales.

headline: Illegal-Immigrant Numbers Stabilize
summary: A two-year decline in the number of illegal immigrants in the U.S. during the recession has halted, according to a new estimate by the Pew Hispanic Center.

headline: Chevron Seeks to Turn Tables in Ecuador Case
summary: Chevron is seeking to turn the tables on the plaintiffs who are suing the company over alleged oil pollution in Ecuador.

headline: Egypt Rises Up
summary: See the protests in Egypt through the lenses of The Wall Street Journal's photographers.

headline: Farmers Insurance in Stadium Naming Deal
summary: Farmers Insurance announced a 30-year deal worth an estimated $650 million to place its name on a proposed downtown Los Angeles football stadium to be called Farmers Field.

headline: Senate Democrats to Begin Earmarks Moratorium
summary: In a reversal, Senate Democrats announced a two-year moratorium on including earmarks, a type of funding for lawmakers' pet projects, in spending bills.

headline: Volt, Leaf Electrics Trickle Out
summary: Nissan and General Motors continued their slow rollout of electric vehicles in January as supplies of the Nissan Leaf and Chevrolet Volt remained limited.

headline: States May Ask High Court to Review Health Law
summary: The 26 states that won a ruling against the new federal health-care law are now weighing whether to ask the U.S. Supreme Court to hear the case before it has been fully litigated in the lower courts.

headline: Floating-Rate Notes Resurface
summary: Corporate borrowers from banks to brewers are switching up the composition of their debt sales, throwing more floating-rate notes into the mix to entice investors who believe interest rates may be about to rise sooner and faster than expected.

headline: Options Traders Position for Small-Cap Slide
summary: The options market saw a handful of big bets that the strong run in small-capitalization stocks will peter out in the next few months.

headline: Euro Rallies Past $1.38
summary: The euro jumped to a two-and-a-half month high against the dollar as investor appetite for riskier assets increased and expectations for an interest-rate hike in the euro zone grew.

headline: Aetna Scales Back in Colorado
summary: Aetna will no longer sell new health-insurance policies to individuals in Colorado, saying it cannot be competitive in the state.

headline: Watchdog Urges Banks to Protect Service Members
summary: Banks must take care to comply with laws meant to protect military families from foreclosures, a federal government military liaison urged them in a warning letter.

headline: Transcontinental Realty Investors, Orexigen Therapeutics: Biggest Price Decliners (TCI, OREX)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Manitowoc, Silicon Motion Technology: Biggest Price Gainers (MTW, SIMO)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Toyota Offers Employee Buyouts
summary: Toyoota Motor, which lost market share for the first time in the U.S. in a dozen years in 2010, is offering incentives to white-collar staff to leave the company.

headline: UPS Profit Increases 48%
summary: United Parcel Service's fourth-quarter profit rose 48%, as corporations and consumers spend more to ship goods in a sign of the improving economy.

headline: JBS Shuffles Top Management
summary: Brazilian meat processor JBS shuffled its senior management to comply with securities regulations.

headline: Massive Storm Marches Across Country
summary: A severe winter storm bore down on a wide swath of the U.S. Tuesday.

headline: ObamaCare Takes Another Licking
summary: U.S. District Judge Roger Vinson minced no words in his decision yesterday that declared ObamaCare unconstitutional.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, another snowstorm slams the U.S., athletes compete in the annual Empire State Building Run-Up, men dress up for a festival in Spain and more.

headline: Palestinians to Hold Municipal Elections
summary: The Western-backed Palestinian government in the West Bank says it will hold local council elections "as soon as possible."

headline: BlackRock CEO Gets $13 Million Bonus
summary: BlackRock awarded Chief Executive Laurence Fink a bonus valued at nearly $13 million in restricted stock and options for leading the world's biggest money manager. It is one of the largest Wall Street bonus awards disclosed this season.

headline: Jury Rules Against BDO
summary: The accounting firm was ordered to pay $91.7 million in damages for fraud and negligence over its auditing of a housing developer that later went bankrupt.

headline: Brent Crude Extends Rally
summary: The main U.S. oil contract retreated on worries over rising supplies, while its European counterpart shot to another two-year high above $102 a barrel.

headline: Morgan Stanley, BofA Offer $1.55 Billion CMBS
summary: Morgan Stanley and Bank of America offered a $1.55 billion commercial mortgage-backed security, according to a person familiar with the matter, marking the second such security to come to market so far this week.

headline: HSBC Sees Pact on Lending
summary: U.K. banks and government are near an agreement on lending commitments, HSBC Chairman Douglas Flint told U.K. lawmakers, as part of a broader effort by banks to show they are doing their part to help revive the economy and improve their public image.

headline: Gold Prices Edge Higher
summary: Gold futures rose slightly as worries about Egypt persisted and fund buying encouraged the market.

headline: Court Dismisses Claim in MBIA-Merrill Suit
summary: A court ruled that the remaining claim should be dismissed in a lawsuit against Merrill Lynch by bond insurer MBIA over credit default swaps.

headline: Morgan Stanley CEO Sees Upside in Fixed Income
summary: Morgan Stanley CEO James Gorman said he sees "significant upside" in the investment bank's fixed-income operations, as he seeks to revive the struggling unit with new hires.

headline: Delinquency Rate Hits Record 9.34%
summary: The delinquency rate for commercial mortgage-backed securities reached a new high in January.

headline: European Stocks Rally on Economic Data
summary: European stock markets rallied, buoyed by strong earnings reports from technology firms and upbeat economic data from the euro zone and the U.S.

headline: Russia: Resignation Won't Harm Sochi
summary: The resignation of the chief construction official for the 2014 Winter Olympics 'will not affect' Russia's preparations for the Sochi Games, the government minister responsible for delivering the event said Tuesday.

headline: Five Colombian Miners Die in Blast
summary: Five miners were killed in a methane blast at a coal mine, marking the second deadly mining disaster in Colombia in less than a week.

headline: Ireland to Vote After Parliament Dissolved
summary: Irish Prime Minister Brian Cowen called for the dissolution of Parliament, kicking off a weeks-long campaign for an election that will likely deliver the biggest shakeup of Ireland's political landscape in modern history.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Settles With Former Execs
summary: Deutsche Telekom AG said Tuesday it has settled a dispute with former chief executive Kai-Uwe Ricke and former chairman Klaus Zumwinkel on compensation claims related to a scandal in which phone log data of supervisory board members and journalists were monitored.

headline: Vodafone, Essar Move on Venture
summary: Vodafone and India's Essar Group appointed bankers to assess the value of the Indian conglomerate's 33% stake in their India joint venture.

headline: Cummins Profit Rises 34%
summary: Cummins's fourth-quarter profit increased 34%, helped by sharply improved sales of power-generating engines.

headline: JGC Nears Settlement With U.S.
summary: JGC, a Japanese contractor, posted amended financial statements on its website late Monday that indicate it's nearing an agreement with the U.S. Justice Department to settle charges it violated the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

headline: Asia's Price Pressures Rise
summary: Manufacturing in Asia continued to expand at a fast clip while price pressures increased further in January, as surging commodities prices add urgency to Asian authorities' efforts to keep inflation under control.

headline: Korea Aims to Tame Prices
summary: South Korea's inflation rate surged in January, prompting the president to warn that the government must act on price pressures—the authorities' biggest economic policy concern.

headline: Macau Gambling Revenue Rises
summary: Gambling revenue in Macau rose 33% in January from a year earlier, reflecting continued strength in the territory's gambling market.

headline: Yemen Leader Summons Parliament
summary: President Ali Abdullah Saleh called for an emergency meeting of Yemen's parliament to be held Wednesday, where he is expected to announce measures aimed at tamping down unrest.

headline: Euro-Zone Manufacturing Gains
summary: Activity in the euro zone's manufacturing sector picked up unexpectedly to a nine-month high in January led by Germany, fueling a surge in inflationary pressures.

headline: Tourists Help Boost U.S. Exports
summary: The number of international visitors to the U.S. rose 10% during the first 11 months of 2010. Tourists spent $122.7 billion through November 2010, up 11% from the same period a year-earlier.

headline: Storm Disrupts Super Bowl Travel
summary: As thousands begin to travel to Dallas for the Super Bowl and fill airline seats, some worry it won't be easy to rebook passengers inconvenienced by the winter storm pounding the area this week.

headline: Biogen Profit Drops 21%
summary: Biogen Idec's profit fell 21% on restructuring charges that outweighed the sales of key drugs.

headline: ADM Posts Higher Profit
summary: Archer Daniels Midland reported a 29% rise in quarterly earnings as the grain-processing giant saw improved demand and pricing for agricultural commodities.

headline: Candidates Emerge in Myanmar
summary: Myanmar's first parliament in more than two decades Tuesday nominated five vice-presidential candidates, one of whom is expected to become president and lead the new military-dominated government.

headline: Manitowoc, Silicon Motion Technology: Biggest Price Gainers (MTW, SIMO)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Vanguard REIT, SPDR S&P Dividend: Money Flow Leaders (VNQ, SDY)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Syrians Call for Protests
summary: Opposition movements in Syria are using social networking sites to mobilize for mass protests this weekend against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad, taking inspiration from Egypt and Tunisia, in the latest sign of how dissent is spreading through the region.

headline: Koreas Meeting Nearly Set
summary: South Korea and North Korea appeared close to agreeing Tuesday to a meeting next week of working-level military officers—the first between the two militaries since Sept. 30—who will attempt to lay groundwork for a later high-level meeting.

headline: Goldman Research Veteran to Retire
summary: Goldman Sachs Group's Laura Conigliaro, co-director of the firm's research division in the Americas and a 30-year veteran in the financial research industry, plans to retire at the end of June.

headline: Japan's Downgrade Upside
summary: A cut in a sovereign bond rating is seldom good news for a country, but in Japan's case, the recent downgrade by Standard & Poor's may benefit the country in the long-term by helping to raise rates of return.

headline: U.K. Manufacturing Expands
summary: The U.K.'s manufacturing sector expanded at the strongest rate for at least 19 years in January, but inflationary pressures are also surging. The U.K. house prices edged lower to register their first drop in annual terms for 17 months.

headline: Floating-Rate Notes Resurface
summary: Corporate borrowers are issuing more floating-rate notes to entice investors, who believe interest rates may be about to rise.

headline: Del Monte Sells $1.3 Billion in Notes
summary: Del Monte Foods sold $1.3 billion of eight-year senior notes, part of a $4.75 billion debt offering to fund its leveraged buyout by a private-equity consortium led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: American Apparel Seeks Loan Amendments
summary: American Apparel is negotiating, again, with its lenders to amend its credit agreements.

headline: Ally Financial Posts Profit, Lends More
summary: Ally Financial, formerly known as GMAC, posted its fourth consecutive quarterly profit as the lender set aside sharply less to cover potential loan losses and as net revenue rose.

headline: McGraw-Hill Profit Falls
summary: McGraw-Hill said its fourth-quarter profit fell 8% due to one-time charges, while its revenue rose 4.1%,

headline: BP Partner Aims to Block Dividend
summary: Alfa-Access-Renova, BP's partner in TNK-BP, upped the ante in its conflict with the U.K. oil giant by agreeing to withhold TNK-BP's $1.8 billion fourth-quarter dividend—a move that could be a big financial blow to BP.

headline: Covered Bonds Not a Panacea
summary: Favored by banks, investors and regulators, euro-denominated issuance of covered bonds set a monthly record in January. However, these secured bonds aren't a silver bullet for the European banking system's funding problems.

headline: Country Garden Profit Doubles
summary: Chinese property developer Country Garden's profit doubled in 2010, as the company aggressively expanded outside its Guangdong base.

headline: TJX Appoints President
summary: TJX said Ernie Herrman will assume the president duties from CEO Carol Meyrowitz. The off-price retailer said the move was part of succession planning and extended the CEO's contract.

headline: Japanese Yields Rise
summary: Japanese government bond yields rose, following U.S. Treasurys in the wake of strong U.S. economic indicators. The auction of 10-year debt was weaker than expected.

headline: Pfizer to Close U.K. Center
summary: U.S. pharmaceutical company Pfizer said it will exit a major research and development center in Sandwich, southern England, over the next 18 to 24 months as part of a global revamp to refocus R&D activities.

headline: Nissan Boost Needed to Rev Up Renault
summary: Renault's Achilles heel remains its poor operating profitability. Improving its cooperation with Renault, possibly by bringing the alliance nearer a full merger, may solve that.

headline: Indian Banks Raise Interest Rates
summary: Several Indian lenders raised their interest rates, in either deposits, loans and in some cases both, roughly a week after the Reserve Bank of India resumed its rate-tightening cycle to tame rising prices.

headline: Baring Raises $2.46 Billion
summary: Baring Private Equity Asia has raised $2.46 billion from investors for deals, one of the largest pools of capital collected in the region by a private-equity fund since the global financial crisis.

headline: Funds Seek Clarity on 'Expert Networks'
summary: An industry group has asked the SEC for guidelines on the use of such firms, which have been under scrutiny in a federal insider-trading probe.

headline: Daiwa Appoints President
summary: Daiwa Securities Group posted its first net profit in four quarters, thanks to a recovery in market conditions and cost cuts. The firm also said it will appoint Deputy President Takashi Hibino as its president effective in April.

headline: Making Imaging Centers Spa-Like
summary: As demand for medical imaging scans grows, hospitals and imaging centers are sprucing up their offerings to attract more of the business.

headline: Android Loosens iPad's Market Grip
summary: Global tablets shipments more than doubled sequentially in the fourth quarter, with Apple's iPad commanding 75% of the market but tablets running Google's Android software winning share.

headline: Here Comes the Year of the Rabbit
summary: The Chinese Lunar New Year falls on Feb. 3 and marks the start of the Year of the Rabbit. In costumes, as pets or adorning shop windows, rabbits are all the rage in China, where even brokerages hope their unifying influence will help bring good fortune in the lunar new year.

headline: A Good Day For Greek Banking
summary: Pireaus Bank has pulled off one of the more unlikely rights issues the market is likely to see this year. Even so, it could be a long wait before the stock can trade closer to book value.

headline: Ukraine Election Set for October 2012
summary: Pro-presidential lawmakers voted to set Ukraine's next parliamentary election for October 2012, a move that further entrenches President Viktor Yanukovych's power by effectively extending the chamber's term by one year.

headline: NTPC Looks to Coal
summary: State-run NTPC plans to produce 45 million tons of coal a year from its own mines by 2017 in an attempt to secure the fossil fuel for its rising power generation capacity and create an additional revenue source.

headline: Rajaratnam Presses for Details of Internal McKinsey Probe
summary: Galleon Group founder Raj Rajaratnam is seeking details of any internal probe by consulting firm McKinsey related to purported leaks by its former head, Rajat Gupta. McKinsey is fighting the request, citing attorney-client privilege.

headline: BofA CEO Gets $9.05 Million Bonus
summary: Bank of America Chief Executive Brian Moynihan received $9.05 million in a deferred-stock bonus, his first performance award for running the bank.

headline: BP CEO Says Injunction Against Rosneft Deal Likely
summary: BP's partners in its Russian joint venture TNK-BP are likely to obtain an injunction to temporarily halt talks between BP and OAO Rosneft about an Arctic exploration deal, BP Chief Executive Bob Dudley said.

headline: Versailles Meets Chappaqua
summary: Pattered after the La Lanterne in Versailles, the owners of this 14-room home in Chappaqua, N.Y., kept France in mind when it came to renovations, landscaping and furnishings.

headline: Asia Mostly Rises Amid Mixed Data
summary: Asian stock markets were mostly higher, with choppy trading in China ahead of this week's Lunar New Year holiday and after data painted a mixed picture of its manufacturing sector.

headline: Daiichi Sankyo Profit Grows 34%
summary: Japan's second-largest pharmaceutical maker by sales said its quarterly net profit grew on sales of blood-pressure drug and strong earnings from its Indian generic-drug unit.

headline: Daimler to Buy More Parts From India
summary: Daimler AG plans to buy more components from India for its global operations and expects growing demand for luxury cars to drive sales higher in the south Asian nation.

headline: Auto-Sector Demand Boosts Infineon
summary: Infineon Technologies raised its forecast after net profit jumped, driven by strong demand from the automotive and industrials sector.

headline: S&P Affirms Spain Rating, Keeps Negative Outlook
summary: Standard and Poor's Corp. Tuesday affirmed its rating on Spain at AA, citing the government's commitment to the current strategy for the budget and structural reforms.

headline: India Auto Makers Post Strong January Sales
summary: India's top auto makers continued to gain from robust demand for new vehicles in January, notching up higher sales despite lifting prices to offset higher input costs.

headline: Daimler Introduces Luxury Sedan in India
summary: Daimler's India unit introduced the luxury Maybach sedan priced between 48.5 million rupees ($1.06 million) and 51 million rupees.

headline: Italy, India Aim to Double Trade
summary: India and Italy are to aim to double bilateral trade to $17.5 billion in the next five years, according to India's Minister for Commerce and Industry.

headline: Indian Shares End at Five-Month Low
summary: Indian shares fell for a fifth straight session Tuesday to close at a five-month low as foreign institutions used early gains to resume selling in stocks such as Reliance Industries.

headline: Smartphones, Tablets Boost ARM Profit
summary: Strong demand for smartphones and tablets helped U.K. microchip designer ARM Holdings deliver a sharp rise in profit in the fourth-quarter.

headline: S&P Cuts Egypt Rating
summary: Standard & Poor's Ratings Services downgraded Egypt's sovereign rating by one notch to double B and warned it may slash it further within the next three months if the political situation there continues to deteriorate.

headline: Egyptians Gather in Main Square
summary: Egyptians from around Cairo filed into the city's central Tahrir Square on Tuesday morning, gathering for a massive day of protest to press longtime President Hosni Mubarak to step down.

headline: DLF to Start Six Realty Projects
summary: DLF, India's largest property developer by sales, plans to start six housing and commercial projects this quarter to raise cash to reduce its large debt.

headline: German Employment Rises
summary: Germany's labor market strongly rebounded in January after December's slip, propelled by the country's economic upswing.

headline: Baidu Net More Than Doubles
summary: Baidu's fourth-quarter earnings more than doubled—and its revenue nearly did—as China's top Internet search engine continued to gain market share.

headline: Coal India Proposes JV for Coal-To-Liquid Project
summary: Coal India has proposed to form a joint venture with NMDC and the government of the eastern province of West Bengal to make liquid fuel from coal, federal Coal Minister Sriprakash Jaiswal said.

headline: Infosys, Wipro Evacuate Staff From Egypt
summary: Indian software companies Infosys Technologies and Wipro said they have moved out their expatriate employees from Egypt because of the political turmoil in the country.

headline: Samsung Offers Refunds for PCs
summary: Samsung Electronics will offer full refunds to customers who have bought its personal computers built with Intel's flawed new chipset.

headline: Australia Keeps Rates Unchanged
summary: Australia's central bank rebuffed concerns over the economy, holding interest rates firm at its first policy meeting since devastating floods wrecked much of Queensland state and caused an estimated $20 billion of damage

headline: Indians Return from Cairo
summary: The Indian government arranged for over 300 Indian nationals to be flown back to Mumbai from Egypt's capital on Monday as political tensions mount in the country. Some snapshots.

headline: Surajkund Mela
summary: North India's Surajkund Mela, an arts and crafts fair, kicks off Tuesday outside New Delhi. Some snapshots.

headline: IMF Warns on Asian Economies
summary: Fast-growing Asian economies face a risk of overheating and may need to tighten monetary policy further, the head of the International Monetary Fund said.

headline: Sanyo Electric Net Loss Widens
summary: Japan's Sanyo Electric, posted a net loss of $112.3 million in the latest quarter, as prices of mainstay rechargeable batteries declined.

headline: Daihatsu Motor Net Profit Rises
summary: Daihatsu Motor Co. said Tuesday its net profit rose 19% in the fiscal third quarter, as the company's shift in focus toward rapidly growing Asian markets supported its bottom line.

headline: India December Exports Up 36.4%
summary: India's merchandise exports rose 36.4% to $22.5 billion in December from a year earlier, according to provisional data issued by the Ministry of Commerce.

headline: India January Manufacturing Expands
summary: Manufacturing activity in India expanded in January, with the pace rising a tad from the previous month.

headline: Aditya Birla to Buy Columbian Chemicals
summary: Diversified Indian conglomerate Aditya Birla Group has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire U.S.-based Columbian Chemicals for $875 million, enlarging its production capacity and expanding its market to the Americas and Europe.

headline: Negotiating the Union
summary: Cartoonist Adrian Tomine gets real in his new book, "Scenes From an Impending Marriage."

headline: Brown's California Plan: Cuts, Taxes
summary: Californians must choose whether to extend temporary tax increases or face deep budget cuts, Gov. Jerry Brown said in his State of the State address.

headline: Peter J. Wallison: What's So Special About the 30-Year Mortgage?
summary: There's nothing wrong with these loans, but there's no good policy reason why taxpayers should subsidize them.

headline: Yes, 'Jhonny Vegas' Is My Real Name
summary: Hurting for characters, golf is warming up to a gregarious kid from Venezuela: Jhonattan Vegas.

headline: Sweet Spot
summary: Japanese dessert bar Kyotofu has long been known for its sweet standouts. Head there for lunch, too, when the menu features such entrees as green tea buckwheat noodles and a chicken and tofu burger.

headline: Returning Identity to Donated Cadavers
summary: A small medical school in Indiana is upending tradition involving donated bodies by compiling cadaver biographies and cultivating relationships with survivors.

headline: Loughner Trial Moved to Tucson
summary: The federal trial of Jared Loughner, the 22-year-old man accused in a mass-shooting on Jan. 8, will be moved to Tucson, where the shootings occurred.

headline: The Constitutional Moment
summary: Judge Vinson introduces ObamaCare to Madison and Marshall.

headline: Cost Inflation Puts a Wrench Into the Works
summary: Good news in the manufacturing sector has come with a sting in its tail.

headline: Net Tightens Around Netflix
summary: The buzz about Amazon possibly launching a streaming-video subscription service underlines the threat of serious competition to Netflix.

headline: He's Quietly Taken the NBA by Surprise
summary: A second-round draft pick of the Knicks, low-key Landry Fields "keeps picking things up at an incredibly fast pace."

headline: Euro Climbs Amid Talk of a Rate Increase
summary: The euro rose against the dollar as speculation mounted that the European Central Bank would raise key interest rates to curb rising inflation, momentarily outweighing concerns about the turmoil in Egypt.

headline: Lagardère's Less Fashionable Future
summary: The French media group's transformation into a more narrowly focused publishing and sports-marketing company remains a work in progress.

headline: Intel Finds Chip-Design Flaw
summary: Intel discovered a design issue in a recently released support chip for its Sandy Bridge processors, prompting it to halt some shipments. It estimated the cost to repair and replace the chip at $700 million.

headline: Nassau Asks Court to  Block Takeover
summary: Nassau County officials filed suit Monday against a state control board that seized control of the affluent community's finances last week, setting the stage for a protracted legal battle.
